prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for kicking a guy out of my hobby group because of his concealed gun?
I am in a little board game group that has been meeting regularly for the past six months. We used to have our game nights at a local hobby shop, but since we've gotten closer and the shop is in not the best part of town, have recently decided to start doing it at my house instead.

There's five of us total and one guy, "Jim" has a concealed carry permit and carries a gun with him. I know this because he's mentioned that he's always armed. I am very anti-gun but it had never come up before. Before our first game night at my place I told Jim privately that I don't want any guns in my house and that he would have to leave his in his truck if he brang it. He gave kind of an acknowledging but not exactly affirming response.

Then after our first game session at my house, one of the other group members told me on her way out that Jim had told her he still had his gun with him while I was in the kitchen out of earshot. I texted Jim and told me he had been extremely disrespectful and that this wasn't a game, and he could not come to my house again if he was going to have a gun on him. His response was "Fine, guess I won't be coming then," and he effectively quit the group.

The reaction with the rest of the group is split. One person doesn't care whether Jim participates or not, one person says it was "harsh but fair" and that Jim wasn't really kicked out per se, and one person thinks I am being a shrew and shouldn't have been so uptight about the gun after just one session, since he's never had to leave it behind before.

My point of view is that it's my house and my rules, and I don't think it's an unreasonable rule to not want a gun in my home. I put my foot down the first time it happened because it was a serious matter and not like he brought the wrong snacks or something. Jim keeps texting me going back and forth between saying "lose my number" and sending me links to propaganda supporting his viewpoint.
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of this situation is in the wrong for kicking someone out of their hobby group because of a concealed gun. The author is anti-gun, and after setting a rule that no guns in the house, Jim still brought his, so the author kicked him out.

First, I need to consider the legal aspect. If the author told Jim that he couldn't have a gun in their house and Jim brought it anyway, the author might have a right to remove him from their property. Since it's their home, they can set rules. But depending on the location, there might be laws about carrying concealed weapons. If Jim had a valid permit, maybe he's allowed to carry in public places, but the author's house is private. However, some places have specific laws about entering private properties with a concealed weapon. The author should check if Jim was legally allowed to be there with the gun, even with a permit. But even if he was legally allowed, the author can still enforce their own rules on private property.

Then there's the social aspect. The author made it clear that guns weren't allowed. Jim didn't comply, so the author followed through by asking him to leave the group. The other group members have mixed reactions, but the author's main point is that it's their house and their rules. The fact that Jim kept texting and sending propaganda after being asked to leave might show that he's not respecting the author's boundaries now, which could make the author's decision look more justified.

However, some might argue that maybe the author could have handled it differently, like having a more thorough discussion or giving Jim a chance to leave the gun elsewhere. But the author did set the rule beforehand and reiterated it when the issue occurred. The situation escalated quickly, but the author's stance is firm. 

So considering all that, the author is not in the wrong because it's their home and they can set boundaries. Jim's actions violated those boundaries, so removing him is a reasonable response. The answer should be B.
